New York University Archives
Mary Agnes Brady papers
Brady, Mary Agnes
MC 186
0.75 Linear Feet in 1 manuscript box and one oversize box
1939 This collection comprises the personal papers of Mary Agnes Brady, graduate student in the School of Education, Health, Nursing, and the Arts Professions (now the Steinhardt School of Culture, Education and Human Development). This collections contains class notes, papers, and assignments relating to theater history, theory, and performance.
Scope and Contents
This collection contains papers, play scripts, stage set designs, costume designs, scrapbooks and course notes by Mary Agnes Brady, a 1939 graduate of the School of Education. Brady's class notes consist of the history, theory, and practice of theater. The two scrapbooks in the collection contain images of costumes and set layouts designed by Brady as well as a script of Romeo and Juliet edited by her.
Access Restrictions
Materials are open without restrictions.
Use Restrictions
Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the creator are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from New York University Archives, (212) 998-2646, university-archives@nyu.edu.
Preferred Citation
Published citations should take the following form: Identification of item, date (if known); Collection Name; MC 186; box number; folder number; New York University Archives
Arrangement
Material is arranged by record type in a single series.
Biography of Mary Agnes Brady
Mary Agnes Brady was a masters student in the School of Education, Health, Nursing, and the Arts Professions concentrating in theater. She earned a Master of Arts degree in 1939. Prior to attending New York University, Brady received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Miami University in 1934.
Preservation Action
Collection contains fragile paper documents. Preservation action, consisting of interleaving with archival paper, was taken on two colored drawings located in "Play Production."
Theater. New York (N.Y.). New York University. School of Education, Health, Nursing, and Arts Profession. Scrapbooks. Notes.
